title: What are Aristotle's criticisms of Plato's ideal state? - Quora

response.answer_text: Aristotle’s criticisms of Plato’s ideal state (as described in the Republic and Laws) are found in his Politics, Book 1, Chapters 1 to 6 (especially Chs. 1 and 2). His chief concern is the infeasibility, impracticality and undesirability of having wives, children and property in common; under this general heading several specific criticisms are made. Rather than list these here, please let me refer you to pp. 102–104 in Susemihl & Hicks (cited below). Hope this helps! References Mayhew, R. Aristotle’s Criticism of Plato’s Republic. Lanham, MD: Rowman & Littlefield, 1997.Müller, Jozef. The Politics of Aristotle’s Criticism of Plato’s Republic. In: S. Weisser & Naly Thaler (eds.), Strategies of Polemics in Greek and Roman Philosophy, Brill (2016), 93-112.Stalley, R. F. Aristotle’s Criticism of Plato’s Republic. In: D. Keyt & F. D. Miller, Jr. (eds.), A Companion to Aristotle’s Politics, Oxford, 1991.Susemihl, Franz, and Robert Drew Hicks. The Politics of Aristotle. London: Macmillan Press, 1894. (alternative link)

Aristotle’s opinion of much of Plato would have been negative. He thought property for instance should be private and each should mind his own business to save quarrels. Also Aristotle believed that if Plato’s plans were good then someone would have thought of them sooner. Surely not the most sophisticated of arguments. I have little time for Plato believing both he and Aristotle were moving in the wrong direction in moving away from the pre-Socratics, but comparing Aristotle with Plato is like comparing a pygmy with a giant.
